awd_titl_txt: Determining how Organic Matter is Stabilized using a Unique Set of Soil Samples from across the U.S.
awd_abstract_narration:
Soil organic matter (SOM) is a critical linkage among many ecosystem services that sustain our society and life on Earth. It is the primary food source for microbes and the principal storehouse of water necessary for plant growth. SOM also stores nutrients for plants and absorbs pollutants that otherwise could contaminate food and water supplies. Soils also help regulate climate by storing carbon that would otherwise be released to the atmosphere and contribute to climate change. This project investigates processes in the soil that protect SOM from being completely consumed by microbes and conversely, processes that could increase its sensitivity  to environmental changes.  The researchers will also study how climate change and changes in how land is managed affect the amount and stability of SOM. The project involves a large number of researchers and laboratories in conducting a wide range of SOM analyses. It takes advantage of soil samples already collected by the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), a major NSF investment in environmental monitoring that covers the entire United States. The samples will be preserved and the data that results from this project made fully public via the web.

The evolution of a new paradigm, where the primary controls on SOM dynamics are less dependent on molecular structure than on other soil and ecosystem properties, has created a knowledge gap in our ability to predict the response of SOM to environmental change. The relationships among shifting controls over different SOM stabilization mechanisms, ranging from distal factors operating at broad spatial scales (e.g., climate) to proximal controls operating at finer spatial scales (e.g., soil physicochemical properties), are poorly defined. Investigators will test the emerging paradigm by quantifying relationships between the dominant mechanisms of SOM stabilization and the scale of the ecosystem controls (i.e., fine-scale, proximal vs. broad-scale, distal) across a continental-scale system of soil types and ecological domains, utilizing soil samples collected during the construction of NEON. This project will be the first continental-scale assessment of SOM vulnerability and will yield new, predictive insights into controls on SOM stability across soil types, land-use types and environmental gradients. The results will significantly improve our understanding of SOM dynamics, a fundamental scientific advancement in its own right, while also enabling better representation of soils in ecosystem and coupled carbon-climate models. The project represents a new standard in open, community-oriented research, supporting participation by researchers from universities, government and non-government agencies. It will facilitate collaboration through major scientific networks that are increasingly necessary to conduct science at the scale needed to address the complex issues facing society. Graduate and undergraduate students will receive training in state-of-the-science methods of soil science by participating in this research, and insights derived from it will inform decisions by policymakers and resource managers concerned with carbon sequestration and ecosystem services.

por.por_cntn:
Soil organic matter is the foundation of soil productivity, water retention, fertility, and pollutant removal and ultimately the supply of food, wood, and fuel for people. Researcher Jeff Hatten (Oregon State University) and colleagues have completed a 6-year investigation into the factors that control the soil's build-up and loss of organic matter. The team of investigators included partners at the University of Michigan, US Forest Service, Colorado University- Boulder, the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), and Virginia Tech. This team completed one of the most detailed comparisons of soils ever conducted using 40 NEON sites across North America. These soils were collected when the NEON sites were being constructed, but they were never planned to be saved for scientific purposes. Instead, the group of investigators preserved half of the samples collected from each site to share with the research community and analyzed the other half. The data set developed from these samples is one of the most comprehensive sources of information describing how organic matter is stored in soils. This dataset was then used to write a set of groundbreaking papers and presentations. The study met all objectives outlined in its original funded proposal. In fulfilling its goals, it advanced the scientific understanding of soil organic matter and the factors influencing its accumulation and loss.  Key findings include:

  • Most soil organic matter takes hundreds to thousands of years to accumulate, but soils can lose a large portion of it in a matter of years to decades with warming, changes in precipitation, or tillage 
  • Soils across the U.S. differ widely in their vulnerability to organic matter loss; these differences are due to variation in soil properties, climate, and vegetation 
  • Some soil organic matter losses are reversible; one of the most rapid and effective means of recovery is the reforestation of lands once under cultivation
  • The most critical factors influencing soil organic matter amounts, accumulation, and loss rates vary depending on the scale at which they are studied: at the continental scale, it's climate; at the local scale, soil physical properties matter more
  • Charred organic matter can be an important source of carbon in grassland and forest soils and may slow the rate of loss during periods of rapid change; however, over long periods it has no relation with soil organic matter turnover.

We communicated this project's scientific results and intellectual merits to the research community via peer-reviewed articles (8 published and 5 currently moving through peer review), book chapters (1), 2 M.S. student theses, 1 PhD dissertation, and at least 19 presentations at professional conferences. The project also had significant broader impacts that included: 1) developing an archive of data and samples made available to the scientific community and 2) training laboratory professionals (1), undergraduate students (2), graduate students (2), and post-graduate scientists (1) to conduct soil organic matter research, analyze data, and communicate results.
